isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 3200, 4200, 4300, 4400, 7300, 7400, 7500, 8500, 8600 - ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 3600, 3800, 4000FBC - BATTERY, CHARGING AND CRANKING SYSTEMS - TROUBLESHOOTING

svcprocinfo.para: Before beginning these test procedures, do the following:

item.para: Make sure the vehicle batteries are at 75% state of charge (SOC) or higher. This represents an open circuit voltage (OCV) of 12.4 volts. Batteries with an OCV of 12 volts or less are either completely discharged or have a dead cell.
Check any light or indicator lamp filaments that are suspected of being open (burned out). This is done to avoid unnecessary extensive circuit checks.
Inspect all connectors for loose or damaged pins, wires, etc. Refer to TEST EQUIPMENT AND CONNECTOR REPAIR section in GROUP 08 - ELECTRICAL in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

When the technician determines that a fuse is blown, while checking its condition, he is directed to locate the cause of the overload condition and to repair it. While no further instruction on this procedure is listed in the diagnostic tables, the common procedure is as follows: isolate sections of the circuit by disconnecting connectors, and measure the resistance to ground to find the circuit that is shorted to ground. Then locate the damaged spot in the wire or connector and repair.

Diagnostics for circuits that are malfunctioning by sticking in the on position are generally not covered in detail. It is assumed that the technician knows to check for a malfunctioning switch, relay, or solenoid.

svcsubproc.title: Batteries and Cables
svcsubproc.para: The standard battery system for the 3600, 3800, and 4000FBC consists of two 12V maintenance-free batteries.

warning.para: When handling batteries, always wear face or eye protection, have water supply available, assure good ventilations, and be sure no open flames are present.

svcsubproc.title: Batteries and Cables - Battery Test Procedure (Figure 12)
svcsubproc.para: Test each battery separately.

step1.para: Disconnect both battery term. cables at each battery. Check each battery visually.
Examine the hydrometer eye (if no eye go to next step).

step2.para: Eye shows green - go to step 4.
Eye shows dark - recharge, then go to step 4.

step1.para: Apply a 300A load for 15 seconds. Turn off load and wait one minute.

step2.para: If 12.4V or more - go to step 4.
If less than 12.4V - recharge, then repeat step 3.

step1.para: Apply a test load equal to 50% of the battery CCA rating at 0°F. After 15 seconds, with the load still applied, measure and record terminal voltage __________. Turn the load off.
Estimate the battery temperature. If measured voltage does not meet or exceed the value shown in the following table, replace the battery.
Clean all cable ends and terminals of the battery with a wire brush.

svcsubproc.title: Batteries and Cables - Battery Cable Voltage Loss Test ( Figure 13).
svcsubproc.para: Slow cranking is often caused by high resistance in the battery cables or connections, especially in cold weather. After all batteries check good ( Battery Test Procedure) and terminals are clean and tight, check the battery cables. To do this, place a specific load on the batteries at the starter and measure the voltage drop in each cable. This load will be supplied by the adjustable carbon pile.

The voltage drop in the positive cable plus the voltage drop in the negative cable equals the difference between the battery voltage and the starter voltage due to the cables. The maximum acceptable loss has been calculated only for the specific load specified in the test.

step1.para: Tighten nuts holding battery cables to the solenoid and starter terminals.

note.para: The solenoid BAT terminal is at battery voltage when batteries are connected.

step1.para: Connect carbon pile positive lead to starter solenoid BAT terminal and negative lead to starter ground terminal.
Connect voltmeter from the starter solenoid "B" terminal to battery positive post.
Turn carbon pile on and adjust load to 500A. Read and record positive cable voltage drop. Turn off the load and allow carbon pile to cool.
Connect voltmeter from negative battery post to starter ground terminal. Attach leads directly to ground studs and not the cables.
Turn carbon pile on and adjust load to 500A. Read and record negative cable voltage drop. Turn off the load.

svcsubproc.para: POSITIVE CABLE Voltage Loss (step 4) __________
NEGATIVE CABLE Voltage Loss (step 6) __________
TOTAL CABLE LOSS__________
If system loss is 0.6V or less, go to Starting Motor System Circuits and Components.
If total cable loss is greater than 0.6V, repair or replace cable(s) with excessive voltage loss and retest.

svcsubproc.title: Starting Motor System Circuits and Components
svcsubproc.para: This section consists of five parts: Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1, Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2, Starter Motor Replacement Test, Engine Crank Inhibit System Circuit Test, and Testing Thermal Overcrank Protection System.

svcsubproc.title: Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1 ( Figure 14)
svcsubproc.para: Starter shifting in and out, or not pulling in, is often caused by high resistance in the starter solenoid circuit. When the solenoid circuit has excessive voltage loss, the starter pinion sometimes may not engage the flywheel. If it does engage, it may drop out too soon when battery voltage drops. The solenoid circuit includes the starter relay (located center of bulkhead) and leads connected to the starter solenoid.
On vehicles with overcrank protection, refer to Testing Thermal Overcrank Protection System before performing this test.

step1.para: Disconnect starter relay circuit 17C from the starter solenoid "S" terminal.

Connect the carbon pile positive lead to circuit 17C and the negative lead to the starter ground. Connect the positive lead of a DMM voltmeter to the solenoid "B" terminal. Connect negative lead of voltmeter to switch wire lead 17C (not to carbon pile clamp). Meter will show battery voltage.

Have an assistant turn the key switch to the start position or push start button. Voltmeter reading should be zero. You should hear the starter relay switch energize with a clicking sound. If the switch doesn't "click," either the starter relay switch is defective or there is no voltage from the key switch circuit (refer to diagnostic test, Engine Crank Inhibit System Circuit Test).

Turn on and adjust the carbon pile to 50 amp load (for no more than 10 seconds). Read and record __________ voltage on voltmeter. Release start switch. Turn off and disconnect carbon pile and voltmeter.

svcsubproc.para: If circuit loss is 0.5 volt or less, solenoid circuitry is OK. Go to Engine Crank Inhibit System Circuit Test.
If circuit loss is more than 0.5 volt, go to Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2.

svcsubproc.title: Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2 (Wire Voltage Loss) (Figure 15)
svcsubproc.para: If voltage loss in Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1 was more than 0.5 volt, the loss is excessive. The loss may be from loose terminals, corrosion, or a worn out starter relay switch. To locate the problem:

step1.para: Disconnect circuit 17C from "S" terminal at starter solenoid. Connect carbon pile to circuit 17C and to starter ground terminal. Turn the carbon pile on (will show 0 amps).
Disconnect starter relay and install a jumper lead to cavity E, circuit 17B.

note.para: Test lead will be at battery voltage.

step1.para: Connect DMM from solenoid BAT terminal to start relay connector cavity E, circuit 17B (will show zero volts).

At relay connector, install other end of jumper lead to cavity A circuit 17C. Turn on and adjust carbon pile to 50 amp load (no more than 10 seconds). Read and record first wire voltage loss. Disconnect DMM.
At relay connector, connect DMM from cavity A, 17C to circuit 17C at carbon pile. Connect to terminal and not to carbon pile clamp.
Turn on and adjust carbon pile to 50 amp load (no more than 10 seconds). Read and record second wire voltage loss. Disconnect and remove jumper lead and DMM.

svcsubproc.para: First Wire Loss (step 3) __________
Second Wire loss (step 5) __________
Total Wiring Loss = __________(0.4V maximum loss)
If wiring loss is 0.4 volt or less, replace starter relay and retest per Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1.
If wiring loss is more than 0.4 volt, repair or replace wire(s), and retest per above mentioned test, Part 1.
If retest results are still above 0.5 volt loss, replace starter relay and retest per above mentioned test, Part 1.

svcsubproc.title: Starter Motor Replacement Test ( Figure 16)
svcsubproc.para: A. COLD WEATHER START MAGNETIC SWITCH PROBLEMS

The start relay can fail to "hold in" during cold weather cranking due to low voltage, even though the switches and circuits check OK. This failure sounds as though the starter is failing to stay engaged to the flywheel. It is caused by low system voltage releasing the relay.
If this condition exists, install jumper wire from circuit 17B to 17C at starter relay connector.

caution.para: The studs or terminals are at battery voltage and the engine should crank when the jumper is connected. Remove jumper to stop cranking.

svcsubproc.para: If the engine cranks properly with jumper in place, replace the relay.
B. CHECKING AVAILABLE VOLTAGE AT STARTER
If all previous tests have been performed, the vehicle batteries and starter wiring have been checked. If the engine still cranks slowly, check available voltage at the starter.

step1.para: While cranking engine, measure voltage between the starter solenoid "BAT" stud and starter motor ground.

step2.para: If voltage is 9.0 volts or more, the problem must be in the starter (or engine). Replace the starter.
If the voltage is less than 9.0 volts, go to step 2.

step1.para: Check the interconnecting cable between the batteries. While cranking, measure the terminal voltage of each battery by touching voltmeter leads to the post of each battery.

step2.para: If the difference between any two battery readings in the same battery box is more than 0.5 volt or any cable is warm to the touch, replace the interconnecting cables.
If cables check OK, the problem must be in the starter (or engine). Replace the starter.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Crank Inhibit System Circuit Test

note.para: Perform Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1 before conducting the following test.

table.title: Engine Crank Inhibit System Circuit Test

entry.para: Using suitable jumper, jump crank motor solenoid "B" terminal to "S" terminal Does crank motor operate?
Go to Starter Motor Replace- ment Test.
Remove start relay (387). At conn. cavity 2, measure voltage from circuit 17F to ground.
At (387) cavity 1, measure voltage from circuit 17B to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 17-FL/17B, then repair.
At conn. (387), measure voltage across cavity 1 circuit 17B, to cavity 4 circuit 17C.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 17C, then repair.
At conn. (387), measure voltage across cavity 1 circuit 17B, to cavity 5 circuit 17D.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuits 17D or 17-G/ 11-GJ, then repair. Install relay. If equipped with thermal overcrank protection refer to Testing Thermal Overcrank Protection System.
Remove crank inhibit relay (661). With auto. trans. in neutral or clutch pedal depressed, turn key on and at cavity 1, measure voltage from circuit 97L to ground.
At (661) cavity 2, measure voltage from circuit 17 (17C with 3600) to ground.
At (661) install jumper from cavity 17 (17C w/3600), to cavity 4 circuit 17F (17A with 3600). Does motor crank?
Locate open or poor connection in circuits 17F or 17A, or connector (2), then repair.
Bench test relay (661) by measuring resistance from terminal 30 to 87A.
Bench test relay (661) by applying +12V to pin 85 and ground to pin 86. Measure resistance across terminal 30 to 87.
Disconnect ECM conn. (379). Turn key on. With automatic transmission in neutral or with clutch pedal released, measure voltage at cavity 26, circuit 97A to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 97A, or dash connector (3), then repair.
With manual transmission and clutch pedal depressed, at (379) cavity 26, measure voltage from circuit 97A to ground.
At crank inhibit relay conn. (661) cavity 5, install jumper from circuit 97H to ground. At (379) cavity 46, measure resistance of circuit 97H to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 97H or dash connector (3), then repair. If condition persists, refer to Engine Diagnostic Manual for trouble- shooting the ECM.
Check fuse H1 for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition and repair. Replace fuse.
At fuse H1 cavity A, measure voltage from circuit 13F to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 13F, then repair.
Is vehicle equipped with a manual transmission?
Disconnect clutch pedal conn. (386). Turn key on and at cavity C, measure voltage from circuit 97AU to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuits 97AU, 97P, dash conn. (2), or neutral switch connector (438), then repair.
Measure resistance of circuit 97L between conn. (386) cavity A, and relay (661) cavity 1/E.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 97L, then repair. If condition persists, replace clutch pedal sw.
At (386), with clutch pedal released, measure switch resistance across term. B to C.
Clutch pedal sw., term. B to C.
Replace clutch pedal switch and reconnect connector (386).
At (386) and with clutch pedal depressed, measure switch resistance across terminal A to C.
Clutch pedal sw., term. A to C.
Clutch pedal sw. and cir. OK. Reconnect (386).
Replace clutch pedal switch and reconnect connector (386).
Disconnect neutral position switch conn. (438). Turn key on and measure voltage from circuit 97P to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 97P or dash connector (2), then repair.
At switch (438) and with transmission in neutral, measure resistance across terminals.
At conn. (438), install jumper wire from circuit 97AU to ground. At crank relay (661) cavity 1, measure resistance of circuit 97L to ground.
Neutral position sw. and circuits OK. Reconnect (438).
Locate open or poor connection in circuits 97AU, 97L, or dash conn. (2) or jumper conn. (386), then repair. Reconnect (438).
Disconnect key switch connector (63). At cavity E, measure voltage from circuit 15 to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 15, then repair.
At key switch, install jumper from conn. (63) cavity E circuit 15, to cavity F circuit 17. Does engine crank?
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 17, then repair.
Cranking system circuitry checks good. If condition persists, refer to Engine Diagnostic Manual to troubleshoot the ECM.
Remove conn. (417) from thermal switch and measure resistance across switch terminals (starter motor must not be hot).
With key in start position, at conn. (417) measure voltage to gnd. at circuit 17D.
Go to Engine Crank Inhibit System Circuit Test
With key in start position, at conn. (417) measure voltage between circuits 17D and 17-G.
Repair open in circuit 17G/11-GJ to cranking motor ground stud.

svcsubproc.title: Vehicle Charging System
svcsubproc.para: This section consists of five parts: Batteries Undercharged, Alternator Tests, Alternator Wiring Test - Part 1, Alternator Wiring Test - Part 2, and Alternator Replacement Test.

svcsubproc.title: Batteries Undercharged
svcsubproc.para: Before beginning test procedures: check battery cables and alternator wiring (especially grounds) for clean, tight connections. Wires and connectors should not be damaged or corroded.
Perform the following checks before removing the alternator from the vehicle.

step1.para: Accessories having been left on for an extended time.

Check alternator drive belt tension (refer to GROUP 12 - ENGINE, Cooling in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for belt tension specifications). As a general rule, if the alternator fan can be rotated by pulling on the fan with one finger, the belt is too loose.
Inspect for defective batteries as described in GROUP 08 - ELECTRICAL, Battery Section in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.
Wiring defects. Visually check wiring, clamps and connections for clean, tight connections, free of damage and corrosion.
With the engine off, check voltage to ground at the BAT terminal of the alternator. A zero reading indicates an open in circuit 2, between the alternator and batteries.
A defective component or wiring defect may be causing a small current drain that is less than the fuse rating for the circuit so the fuse does not open. To locate the unwanted current drain:

note.para: Batteries should be fully charged for the following test.

step2.para: KEY OFF - turn all accessories and controls off. Disconnect circuit 2 from the alternator B terminal.

To check entire system for current drains, insert DMM leads in the COM and 10A fused jack on the meter. Set the meter to DC Amps. Connect meter in series with the alternator. If meter leads are not connected with correct polarity, a (-) amp reading will be present.
Some current draw will be present. If the current draw is less than 0.3A move the lead from the 10A jack to the 320mA jack to read the exact current flow.

Refer to the Battery Power Distribution circuit diagrams in CTS-5123V. Remove the battery feed fuses one at a time, while monitoring the meter for any change in current flow. Note that some circuits (such as clock or radio or engine computer, etc.) should be drawing some current. Look for current draw in circuits that should not be active.

svcsubproc.title: Alternator Tests
svcsubproc.para: The alternator output must reach the batteries and accessory loads with a minimum amount of voltage loss. Any loss slows the rate of charge to the batteries and can cause the batteries to be undercharged. Discharged batteries can damage the starter and cause vehicle electrical components to operate improperly.

Most alternators control the maximum system voltage using a voltage regulator. Maximum voltage output is available at the alternator BAT terminal, but if any voltage is lost in the wiring, something less than the maximum will reach the batteries and load devices. The greatest losses occur when the charging system is outputting at the maximum rated level (amps).

svcsubproc.title: Alternator Wiring Test - Part 1 (Figure 17)
svcsubproc.para: Instead of using alternator current output this test (and Alternator Wiring Test - Part 2) uses the same amount of current but draws it from the batteries (must be fully charged). Using the carbon pile load, the current flows in reverse through the circuit without the engine running.

step1.para: Without the engine running, connect the carbon pile to the alternator output terminal and ground.

note.para: Alternator output is at battery voltage.

step1.para: Connect voltmeter across battery.
Adjust the carbon pile to alternator rated output (amps). Rated output is stamped on the case or on a tag.
Measure and record BATTERY VOLTAGE. Turn the carbon pile off.
Move the voltmeter to the alternator, but do not connect to carbon pile clamps. Adjust carbon pile to rated output (amps) of the alternator.
Measure and record ALTERNATOR VOLTAGE. Turn carbon pile off.

svcsubproc.para: BATTERY Voltage (step 4) ___________
ALTERNATOR Voltage (step 6) __________
SYSTEM LOSS __________
If system loss is 0.7V or less, go to Alternator Replacement Test.
If system loss is greater than 0.7V, go to Alternator Wiring Test - Part 2.

svcsubproc.title: Alternator Wiring Test - Part 2 (12 Volt System Only) ( Figure 18)
svcsubproc.para: If system voltage is MORE than 0.7V in Alternator Wiring Test - Part 1, perform this test.

step1.para: With the carbon pile still connected, connect Fluke 88 meter to alternator BAT terminal and to positive battery terminal.
Adjust carbon pile to alternator rated output (amps). Measure and record POSITIVE CIRCUIT LOSS. Turn carbon pile off.
Connect the meter from the alternator ground to the battery negative terminal.
Adjust the carbon pile to alternator rated output (amps). Measure and record NEGATIVE CIRCUIT LOSS. Turn carbon pile off.
POSITIVE CIRCUIT LOSS (step 2) ___________
NEGATIVE CIRCUIT LOSS (step 4) ___________
TOTAL SYSTEM LOSS ____________

svcsubproc.para: If system loss is 0.7V or less, go to Alternator Replacement Test.
If system loss is greater than 0.7V, repair circuit(s) defects, then go to Alternator Replacement Test.

svcsubproc.title: Alternator Replacement Test (12 Volt System Only) (Figure 19)

step1.para: If the wiring tests have been performed (circuits OK), adjust alternator belt and tighten mounting bolts and ground connections.

With vehicle at shop temperature, connect the carbon pile, voltmeter (for step 3) and the ammeter (for step 4) as shown. To use an ammeter without induction clamp, connect meter leads to same terminals as the carbon pile.
With NO electrical loads turned on, start the engine. Fast idle until voltage stabilizes (does not increase for 2 minutes). Voltage then should not exceed 15V.
Speed up the engine and turn on the carbon pile until the ammeter shows output has reached the highest value. Record the value______ A. Turn off carbon pile and the engine.
Rated output is stamped on the alternator case or on a tag. If current output measured is not within 10% of rated output or the voltage exceeds 15V, replace the alternator.

entry.para: Check fuse D1 for open condition. Fuse OK?
Locate cause of overload condition and repair. Replace fuse.
At fuse D1, measure voltage from circuit 12 to ground.
Locate cause of no or low voltage condition in cir. 12, then repair.
Disconnect ether switch connector. Turn key on and measure voltage from circuit 21 to ground.
Locate cause of no or low voltage condition in circuit 39/21, then repair.
With ether switch on, measure resistance across switch cavity A and B.
Ether sw., cav. A to B.
Reconnect ether switch connector and disconnect control valve connector (500). With ether switch depressed, measure voltage from circuit 21A to ground.
Locate cause of no or low voltage condition in circuit 21A or dash conn. (2) [also, front end conn. (413) w/3800, 4000FBC], then repair.
Disconnect thermal switch connector. With switch cooled to below 40°F, measure resistance from feed terminal to ground.
Thermal sw., feed term. to gnd.
Reconnect thermal switch connector. At control valve connector (500) and with ether switch depressed, measure voltage from circuit 21A to 21B.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit or 21B, then repair.
At ether bottle control valve pigtail (500), measure resistance across leads.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 21B or 21C. If none found, replace ether bottle control valve.
